text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
we are going to make a side dish now this side

dish is very popular entire restaurants in North 
America as far as I know and that is coconut rice

or what we call kao mun kao means rice and mun 
just means fatty the strange thing is in Thailand

we don't actually eat common very often at all the 
only time we serve kalman is with papaya salad so

it's a bit surprising when I came over here and 
see them offer it all over the place in Thai

restaurants as sort of the alternative to jasmine 
rice now having said that I'm what I'm about to

show you you're more than welcome and use it you 
serve it with whatever you want but since I showed

you a variation of some thumb last week it's you 
know it seems appropriate to show the coconut rice

this week so I want to note though that this 
coconut rice is savory and it's jasmine rice

it is not the same as the sweet coconut sticky 
rice that goes with mango and sticky rice that's

a whole other animal so the first thing we're 
going to do is mix our liquid so this is just

the in search of my rice cooker if you want to do 
this stovetop you can use like a medium sized pot

no problem so in goes my coconut milk now I'm 
doing 1 cup of rice and I've got half a cup of

coconut milk I'm going to dilute that with 3/4 
of a cup of water now I want to note ratios here

okay this is all about ratios cooking is all about 
ratios those two ratios going on one is the ratio

between rice and liquid and that is one part rice 
and 1 and 1/4 part liquid that does not apply to

all types of rice it works for jasmine rice most 
of the time but if you're not using jasmine rice

you may need more or less liquid okay but that 
for me seems to work most of the time and the

other ratio we need to pay attention to is between 
the coconut milk and water the more coconut milk

you use the richer the rice is going to be which 
may be good or not good depending on what you're

serving this with if you're serving this with 
papaya salad like we often do you can go pretty

rich as the pious salad is so light and refreshing 
but if you're also going to serve barbecue chicken

alongside it which is also what we serve coconut 
rice with its coconut rice with haya salad and

barbeque chicken is usually the common trio so 
if there's barbeque chicken you may not want

to make their rice super rich because the chicken 
itself is quite heavy so it's all about balancing

the meal okay so the ratio that I just gave you I 
think is a good sort of middle-of-the-road ratio

and it might also depend on how rich or thick your 
coconut milk is so start with this and then play

around with it for your next batch okay we're 
going to season it a little bit with salt and

also a heaping tablespoon of sugar now this amount 
of sugar is actually not going to make the rice

all that sweet but the sweetness is going to bring 
out the flavor of the coconut a little bit more so

we're still keeping this pretty savory some people 
do like making their coconut rice distinctly sweet

I don't like doing that because the line between 
savory and sweet starts blurring at that point

but if that's what you like doing it's an option 
for you so what I'm gonna do here is I'm going to

put this on to my rice cooker and then heat it 
up until it's warm because once it's warm then

I know that my sugar and salt is dissolved so I'll 
give this a quick stir for now I'm going to put it

in my rice cooker over here turn it on and while 
that's heating up we're going to wash our rice

so I've got here one cup of jasmine rice that I'm 
going to rinse twice in cold water and reason the

reason you want to wash your rice is so that you 
get rid of the excess starch which is what keeps

the rice sticky and prevents the grains from 
separating nicely so see all this cloudy stuff

yeah that's the excess starch so we're going to 
get rid of that and do it one more time we want

to strain this quite well because we've already 
measured our rice to the exact Mei our liquid to

the exact ratio okay so I'm going to let that sit 
and wait for our rice to heat up oh wait I meant

wait for our liquid to heat up so our liquid is 
warmed up now and again the only reason why we

want to heat this up is so that our salt and sugar 
is dissolved some people like to also put pandan

leaf in this to add sort of added aroma to the 
rice I don't really like doing that I feel like

it's a little too floral for savory food but if 
that's what you want to do you can add half a

leaf is enough for this amount add it into this 
liquid here and let it come to a simmer so that

the leaf has a chance to really infuse before you 
add your rice cake I'm going to add my rice mmm it

smells so good give it a stir just to make sure 
there's no clumps of rice and then that did you

just close the lid and let the rice cooker do 
its thing if you're doing this stovetop I will

warn you because there is sugar and fat in this 
liquid it will be extra easy to get that burnt

bottom so if you cook it on the stove make sure 
you let the rice simmer on very low heat and pay

attention to it take it off the heat as soon as 
it's done okay because you wait if you let it

sit too long you'll get that crusty bottom which 
you might not be a bad thing if you like eating

that stuff so I'll be right back so our rice is 
done now I'm sure many of you already know this

but when you cook with a rice cooker when it 
clicks don't touch it for another ten minute

it needs to rest so that the rest of the moisture 
can be fully absorbed into the rice are you ready

that's it ah mmm smells so good okay so you want 
to fluff it I always get a little bit of a brown

bottom with this rice cooker so I always make sure 
not to scrape all the way to the bottom but if you

don't care it's it's not technically burned it's 
just caramelized you're wondering what should I

serve this with well as I said earlier normally we 
serve this with papaya salad and barbecue chicken

guy yeah I have a video for that as well it's an 
old old video but really you can serve this with

whatever you want now when you serve this at 
a party it's a really great way to to sort of

make your side dish a little more elegant and 
instead of serving jasmine rice you're serving

coconut rice so I like to put a little bit of 
toasted coconut this is not traditional by the

way but I just feel that if you set this out on a 
table with nothing in it people are going to think

it's just regular rice and you know maybe people 
don't like coconut so they need to be warned it's

just a little bit on top just to sort of tell 
people that hey this is not just regular rice

you can also do sesame seeds but then sesame seeds 
wouldn't really represent anything but if you just

want something pretty totally that's so pretty 
now I'm going to try this with the thumb panko

pot that I made last week how should I do this 
so this is the the same type of salad that I

showed you last week right the non papaya papaya 
salad made with corn and cucumber and it actually

goes really well with this rice so I'm going to 
have a little bit yeah and then the sauce coats

the rice and beet acidity and everything just 
mixes really well mmm sometimes I eat this and

I'm literally just believe how good this is so 
I totally encourage you to try it it's so easy

it takes just as much time as it would take you 
to make regular rice so you're serving something

that's not overly heavy and you want something to 
you know to really impress your guests a little

bit further try this coconut rice and when you try 
it out let me know how it goes you can contact me

through my website Twitter Facebook Instagram if 
you enjoy the show please click to subscribe so I

can keep producing these videos for you and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious title
